page.title: 3.6.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will compute and interpret the correlation coefficient for a bivariate, numerical data set.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe the strength of a relationship between two variables.

  • Analyze connections between two variables to determine whether or not there is a causal relationship.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 3.6.1: Describing the Relationship between Variables
  • 3.6.2: Describing How Two Variables Are Related
  • 3.6.2: Self Check
  • 3.6.3: Using the Term Causal Relationship
  • 3.6.3: Self Check
  • 3.6.4: Determining the Type of Relationship
After that, you’ll practice and review.
  • 3.6.5: Practice
  • 3.6.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 3.6.1: Describe the Relationship between Variables
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Describe the strength and sign of the relationship you expect for each pair of variables. Explain your reasoning.

1. Used car price and original sale price of the car

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Strong, positive relationship since a car that cost a lot at first is probably still worth more later than a car that was less expensive when it was first bought.

2. Used car price and number of cup holders in the car

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Weak to no relationship. Although it is useful to have some cup holders, very little of a car’s value is based on the number present in the car.

3. Used car price and number of oil changes the car has had

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Strong, negative relationship since cars usually have their oil changed every few thousand miles or every few months, so a lot of oil changes indicates the car has either been driven very far or owned for a long time, so it is probably worth less than a car with fewer oil changes.

4. Used car price and number of miles the car has been driven

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Strong, negative relationship since the number of miles a car has been driven usually indicates more wear on the engine and other car parts, so the car is not worth as much as a car that has been driven less.

page.title: 3.6.2: Describing How Two Variables Are Related
page.contents:
Activity

Each of the scatter plots shows a strong relationship. Write a sentence or two describing how you think the variables are related.

1. During the month of April, Elena keeps track of the number of inches of rain recorded for the day and the percentage of people who come to school with rain jackets.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

When there is more rain, it is more likely people will wear jackets.


2. A school book club has a list of 100 books for its members to read. They keep track of the number of pages in the books the members read from the list and the amount of time it took to read the book.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Longer books will take more time to read.


3. Number of tickets left for holiday parties at a venue and noise level at the party


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

When more tickets are left, the party will have fewer people to have loud conversations, so it will be quieter.


4. The height and score on a test of vocabulary for several children ages 6 to 13


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Children who are taller are usually older, so they have had more time to be in school and learn more vocabulary.

page.title: 3.6.2: Self Check
page.contents: In this scatter plot, which sentence best describes how the two variables are related?

answer.answer_text: The more hot dogs that are bought, the more sodas that are bought.
answer.response: Incorrect. The scatter plot shows the price of hot dogs and sodas and how they are related, not the quantity bought. The answer is: At different locations, as hot dog prices increase, small soda prices also increase.

answer.answer_text: Hot dog prices and small soft drink prices are not related.
answer.response: Incorrect. The scatter plot shows a relatively strong positive relationship. The answer is: At different locations, as hot dog prices increase, small soda prices also increase.

answer.answer_text: At different locations, as hot dog prices increase, small soda prices also increase.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: As a general trend, as the hot dog prices go up, so do the soft drink prices.

answer.answer_text: As hot dog prices go up, soft drink prices go down.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This describes a negative relationship, but the scatter plot shows a positive relationship. The answer is: At different locations, as hot dog prices increase, small soda prices also increase.

page.title: 3.6.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Casual Relationships

Example

A panel is rating different kinds of potato chips. The scatter plot below shows the relationship between their average rating and the price of the chips, along with the line of best fit. How could the variables be related?



As the price of a bag of chips in dollars increases, the average rating of the bag of chips in points increases.

Try It: Describing a Relationship Using a Scatter Plot



The scatter plot shows a strong relationship. How could the variables be related?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

As a car gets older, it is expected to have been driven more and have more miles on it as the years go by.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I'd like to retry the self check.
I'm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 3.6.3: Using the Term Causal Relationship
page.contents:
Activity

The phrases “correlation, not causation” or “association, not causation” are often used to refer to situations in which there is a relationship, but it is not a causal relationship. While correlation used to describe the strength of the relationship between variables, a causal relationship means that a change in one of the variables actually causes a change in the other variable.

Describe a pair of variables with each condition. Explain your reasoning.

1. Two variables have a causal relationship.

Enter your answer to the question here:

Compare your answer:

Length of a person’s feet in inches and their men’s shoe size. Increased foot size would cause someone to purchase larger shoe sizes.


2. The variables are strongly related, but a third factor might be the cause for the changes in the variables.

Enter your answer to the question here:

Compare your answer:

Amount of power produced by solar panels and the percentage of people wearing sunglasses while driving. These factors are probably strongly, positively related, but the cause is the amount of sunlight getting through to the ground for each variable rather than either one of the variables causing the other to increase directly.


3. The variables are not related.

Enter your answer to the question here:

Compare your answer:

The number of hits by a certain baseball player per game for a season and the price of a barrel of oil on the day of the games. There is no reasonable relationship between the variables, and they are very unlikely to be related even by external causes.


Making a Real-World Connection

1. Look through news articles or advertisements for claims of causation or correlation. Find 2 or 3 claims and read or watch the articles or the advertisements. Answer these questions for each of the claims.

  1. What is the claim?

  2. What evidence is provided for the claim?

  3. Does there appear to be evidence for causation or correlation? Explain your thinking.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  1. Claim 1: Green tea lowers blood pressure. Claim 2: Chocolate improves health. Claim 3: Soda helps with heartburn.

  2. Claim 1: Study groups were given either green tea or a drink that was colored like green tea for several weeks, and their blood pressure was taken before and after the study. Claim 2: They analyzed the number of antioxidants in chocolate as compared to fruit. Claim 3: No evidence was provided other than that it seemed to work for some people.

  3. Claim 1: There appears to be evidence for correlation because there was a control group, and the blood pressure was taken before and after drinking tea. However, there was no mention of how the groups were randomized or selected, so I am not sure if there is evidence for causation. Claim 2: The only evidence provided is the quantity of antioxidants chocolate contains, so a study would need to be done on antioxidants and health to show correlation or causation. Claim 3: There is no evidence for correlation or causation because only a testimonial is provided.


2. Choose the claim with the least or no evidence. Describe an experiment or other way that you could collect data to show correlation or causation.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

To show that heartburn relief is correlated with or caused by drinking soda, I would have to randomly assign subjects to different treatment groups. One group would get soda, and the other would get a placebo. I would then need to collect and compare data about their heartburn symptoms to determine if there is correlation or causation.

page.title: 3.6.4: Determining the Type of Relationship
page.contents:
For each pair of variables, decide whether there is:

  • a very weak or no relationship
  • a strong relationship that is not a causal relationship
  • a causal relationship

1. Number of snow plows owned by a city and mitten sales in the city

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer.

A strong relationship that is not a causal relationship. The variables are related since cities with more snow plows will probably also have high sales of mittens compared to places with fewer snow plows. The climate, number of people living in the city, and amount of snow all affect both of these variables. A city having extra snow plows would not cause people to buy more mittens, nor would the reverse happen.

2. Number of text messages sent per day by a person and number of shirts owned by the person

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer.

A very weak or no relationship. These variables seem unrelated, and there is not another variable like age or wealth that would seem to be related to both of these variables consistently.

3. Price of a pizza and number of calories in the pizza

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer.

A strong relationship that is not a causal relationship. The variables are related since a more expensive pizza will generally be larger or have more toppings, leading to more calories, but it is the size or number of toppings that is the cause for the increase in both variables.

4. Amount of gas used on a trip and number of miles driven on the trip

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer.

Causal relationship. Longer trips will cause greater gas consumption, and shorter trips will require less gas.

Video: Determining the Type of Relationship 

Watch the following video to learn more about using the term causal relationship.

page.title: 3.6.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following is a causal relationship?

answer.answer_text: The number of kids in a family and the number of pets in a family.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The number of kids in a family does not cause the number of pets in a family to change. The answer is: The size of a deck and number of wood boards used.

answer.answer_text: The temperature and number of people buying hot chocolate.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let‘s try again a different way: Depending on the weather, more people may buy hot chocolate, but it does not mean the weather will cause people to buy more hot chocolate. The answer is: The size of a deck and number of wood boards used.

answer.answer_text: The size of a deck and number of wood boards used.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: A larger deck causes more boards to be used.

answer.answer_text: The lower the temperature, the more people go ice skating.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let‘s try again a different way: When the temperature decreases, it does not cause more people to ice skate. Other factors also contribute. The answer is: The size of a deck and number of wood boards used.

page.title: 3.6.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Is It Causation?

Correlation means there is a relationship or pattern between the values of two variables. A scatter plot displays data about two variables as a set of points in the \( xy \)-plane and is a useful tool for determining if there is a correlation between the variables.

Causation means that one event causes another event to occur. Causation can only be determined from an appropriately designed experiment. In such experiments, similar groups receive different treatments, and the outcomes of each group are studied. We can only conclude that a treatment causes an effect if the groups have noticeably different outcomes.

Why doesn’t correlation mean causation?

Even if there is a correlation between two variables, we cannot conclude that a change in one variable causes a change in the other. This relationship could be coincidental, or a third factor may be causing both variables to change.

Example

Liam collected data on the sales of ice cream cones and air conditioners in his hometown. He found that when ice cream sales were low, air conditioner sales tended to be low, and that when ice cream sales were high, air conditioner sales tended to be high.

Liam can conclude that sales of ice cream cones and air conditioners are positively correlated.

Liam can’t conclude that selling more ice cream cones causes more air conditioners to be sold. It is likely that the increases in the sales of both ice cream cones and air conditioners are caused by a third factor, an increase in temperature!

Try It: Is It Causation?

Vivek notices that students in his class with larger shoe sizes tend to have higher grade point averages. Based on this observation, what is the best description of the relationship between shoe size and grade point average?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

The relationship has a positive correlation because as shoe size increases, grade point average tends to increase. There is not a causal relationship.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I'd like to retry the self check.
I'm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 3.6.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Analyze connections between two variables to determine whether or not there is a causal relationship.

Here are theactivitiesthat helped you reach those goals:

  • 3.6.1: Describing the Relationship between Variables
    • In this activity, you described the relationship between variables using mathematical terminology, such as strong or weak relationship and positive or negative relationship.
  • 3.6.2: Describing How Two Variables Are Related
    • In this activity, you described how two variables are related and determined whether or not there is a causal relationship. You began to recognize that some variables may be related, but one does not always cause the other to change. You were able to recognize that at this point, the mathematics of scatter plot analysis cannot determine whether there is a causal relationship. You recognized that the relationship must be thought through carefully to decide, based on the situation, whether the related variables have a causal relationship.
  • 3.6.2: Self Check
  • 3.6.3: Using the Term Causal Relationship
    • In this activity, you practiced using the term causal relationship and thought of situations to which it might apply and whether relationships were causal.
  • 3.6.3: Self Check
  • 3.6.4:Determining the Type of Relationship
    • In this activity, you decided if variable pairs had a very weak or no relationship, a strong relationship that is not a causal relationship, or a causal relationship.

After these activities, you completed the followingpractice:

  • 3.6.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

page.title: 3.6.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. Chloe creates a scatter plot showing the relationship between the number of steps she takes and her heart rate. The correlation coefficient of the line of best fit is 0.88.

Are they correlated? Explain your reasoning.

Correct! Yes, the correlation coefficient is close to 1.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 3.6.3–3.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Yes, the correlation coefficient is close to 1, so they are correlated. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. Kiran creates a scatter plot showing the relationship between the number of students attending drama club and the number of students attending poetry club each week. The correlation coefficient for the line of best fit is –0.36.

Are they strongly correlated? Explain your reasoning.

Correct! No, the correlation coefficient is closer to 0.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 3.6.3–3.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: No, the correlation coefficient is closer to 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. Which of the following is a causal relationship?

Correct! The number of minutes spent running and the number of calories burned.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The number of minutes spent running and the number of calories burned. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. Which of the following is a causal relationship?

Correct! The number of miles driven and the cost of gas.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The number of miles driven and the cost of gas. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
